title: refactor SQL index
body:
Instead of passing in the SQLAlchemy engine, have GPTStructStoreIndex take in a SQLDatabase (a subclass of Langchain's SQLDatabase), and use the table_info stored in SQLDatabase rather than a single table at a time. We also expose SQLDatabase publicly in the docs.

This allows users to specify which tables they want to use in SQLDatabase with the `include_tables` parameter. This means that text-to-SQL can also do joins over multiple tables.

Currently we can still only do schema extraction for a single table; that's a TODO for later

title: Run index operations in the background
Fix embedding mode for GPTSimpleVectorIndex
body:
Correct documentation, but also have mode="embedding" behave the same as mode="default" for vector indices. 

Closes #222

title: query mode "embedding" not supported by GPTSimpleVectorIndex?
body:
According to the documentation, GPTSimpleVectorIndex may be queried with "embedding" mode (last example of https://gpt-index.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/embeddings.html).  However when I do so, I get an error.

```python

embed_model = LangchainEmbedding(HuggingFaceEmbeddings())
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.load_from_disk(
    save_path="index.json",
    embed_model=embed_model,
)

response = index.query(
    query_string,     
    mode="embedding",
)
```

error:

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/gpt_index/indices/base.py", line 334, in query
    return query_runner.query(query_str, self._index_struct)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/gpt_index/indices/query/query_runner.py", line 100, in query
    query_cls = get_query_cls(index_struct_type, mode)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/gpt_index/indices/query/query_map.py", line 79, in get_query_cls
    return MODE_TO_QUERY_MAP_SIMPLE[mode]
```

Is this an actual error or is it not possible/recommended to use embeddings with GPTSimpleVectorIndex?  If I use Tree or List indices, then when I save them to disk, there are no actual embeddings, so I am confused on the correct set of classes to use for top-k embedding based queries.

title: Add DONUT model for parsing image documents
body:
Hi,

Made a PR for parsing image documents that contain a lot of (key, value) pairs of information in the images. gpt-index can directly query on top of this to answer values wrt certain keys.

Regards,
Ravi Theja.

title: Error Recovery Part (ii): pick up where you left off
body:
Now that we've added retries with exponential backoff in https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/pull/215, it would be cool to add support for "picking up where you left off". From the example in https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/issues/210:
```
>>> index = GPTTreeIndex(documents, prompt_helper=prompt_helper)
> Building index from nodes: 502 chunks
0/5029
10/5029
20/5029
30/5029
40/5029
50/5029
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
// stack trace and error
```

If we run `index = GPTTreeIndex(documents, prompt_helper=prompt_helper)`, we'd have to start from the beginning. With 502 chunks above, that's a lot of computation we'd be redoing, not to mention token budget gone to waste! 

It would be cool if this happened instead:
```
>>> index = GPTTreeIndex(documents, prompt_helper=prompt_helper)
> Building index from nodes: 502 chunks
> continuing from chunk 50:
50/5029
60/5029
...
// hopefully no errors this time
```

I can think of two ways this might be done:

1. The some global in `gpt_index` tracks some state that stores the results of the computation from the failed run. This might not be great since tracking state like this is confusing
2. If we run into errors during, say, the build step of the index, we return some result anyway, which can then be fed into the next call of `GPTTreeIndex(documents, prompt_helper=prompt_helper)`. This might be possible today with index composability? 

If we added support for this, I believe that this will give developers more confidence to index larger sets of documents.

title: Add metadata to Document nodes and integrate with file reader
body:
Enables Document metadata to be included in queries by prepending it to each node. Includes the work from #216. Metadata can now also be printed when listing the source documents on queries.

Moreover, `SimpleDirectoryReader` now has the following improvements:
- Ability to pass in an arg to specify the metadata for each file (useful to list things like author, title, date, extension, etc). This is useful since there's often a need to reference metadata when reading lots of files, e.g. research papers or code files. Anecdotally, this has improved performance quite a bit.
- Print the total # of files read
- Ability to read docx files using lightweight package

I also added a test for `file_metadata`

title: Manipulating GPT Responses (Prefixes & Prompting for Formatting)
body:
I'm querying GPT with a table like:

Name:
Date:
Location:
SF:

And would love for the response to just be the answer alone since I am writing the answer to an excel file that already has the table so my result ends up looking like:

Name: Name: Bob
Date: Date: 1/1/2023
Location: Location: New York
SF: SF: 2000 square feet
Months: Months: 20 months

1. How do I prevent it from repeating the question in this way
2. How do I prevent it from providing units (i.e 2000 "square feet" vs. "2000")

Thank you!

title: [WIP] have metadata/extra_info be in each text chunk
body: Allows additional document metadata (either manually specified or automatically extracted) to be passed to each text chunk for higher-level context.

title: Add retries with exponential backoff
body: Addresses #210.

title: Add web page loader
body:
Add both `SimpleWebPageReader` and `TrafilaturaWebReader` classes.

Also add an example notebook

title: Fix + small addition to SimpleDirectoryReader
body:
Previously, the `recursive` attribute was not being used. The reader always recursively read subdirectories even though the attribute is `False` by default. This is fixed.

I also added a new attribute to limit the number of files added to the reader when the recursion can go deep. The recursion still finishes (not a worry) but it avoids having too many Documents created. I switched the resulting `new_input_files` array to reflect BFS instead of DFS and so the file limit prioritizes top-level files.

title: Update docs: response object, embedding support, updates
Indexing should recover from errors more gracefully
body:
I've been trying to generate a tree index, but I'm hitting OAI ratelimits. The problem is that this forces me to start the index from scratch again, which is time-consuming and expensive.

If a ratelimit gets hit, the index should retry, or at the very least save some sort of intermediate state so you can resume indexing later.

title: Allow passing table parameter to GPTSQLStructStoreIndex
body:
PR to address: https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/issues/203

Core issue:  In SQLAlchemy `MetaData(bind=self._engine).reflect()` only returns metadata for tables, not views.

However, it is still possible to get view metadata explicitly with
```
my_view = Table('some_view', MetaData(bind=engine), autoload=True)
```
See https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/reflection.html#reflecting-views for details

Amongst the suggestions in that documentation is that for views you may want to specific additional context, such as hints on primary and foreign keys:
```
my_view = Table(
    "some_view",
    metadata,
    Column("view_id", Integer, primary_key=True),
    Column("related_thing", Integer, ForeignKey("othertable.thing_id")),
    autoload_with=engine,
)
```

So we have one possible option of simply replacing 
```
table = self.sql_database.metadata_obj.tables[table_name]
```
with
```
table = Table(tablename, autolad_with=engine)
```
However the issue with that is that it doesn't allow us to easily specify those primary and foreign key constraints easily. (*)

Which leads to the approach taken here: allow the creator of the GPTSQLStructStoreIndex to pass the `table` structure in instead of the `table_name`.


(*) That said there is a general case performance improvement that we could make by doing this in favor of the full `metadata_obj.reflect()` that currently exists in the SQLDatabase object.  We only need metadata for the one table, and the full reflect() will do the entire schema.  This is outside the scope of what this PR is trying to achieve, so is not included.

title: Add pdf reader
body:
Hi,

Added pdf reader using PyPDF2 to SimpleDirectoryReader in file.py. This makes life easier to extract text from PDF files and query over it.

Thank you.

title: Fix minor grammar and punctuation issues
Fix typo in query_runner.py
body: arugments -> arguments

title: New feature: Add compability with more file formats for SimpleDirectoryReader
body: While the SimpleDirectoryReader is very efficient and allows to simply query a (set of) text file(s) with very few lines of code, it would be great if the data connector was able to ingest more file formats such as PDF for example.

title: Feature Request: Example of using a preloaded SQLIndex without document extraction
body:
SQLIndexDemo is an interesting starting point, would be helpful to have an example usecase leveraging a pre-loaded database rather than creating a database based on unstructured document parsing. 

 E.g. it is non obvious how to correctly set documents/index_struct when the data is already loaded.

title: GPTSQLStructStoreIndex does not work with views
body:
SQL Alchemy does not load view metadata on:

`SQLDatabase`
```
    def __init__(self, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> None:
        """Init params."""
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.metadata_obj = MetaData(bind=self._engine)
        self.metadata_obj.reflect()
```

Which causes the initialization of the index to fail with a `KeyError`

`GPTSQLStructStoreIndex`
```
 def __init__(...):
    ...
    table = self.sql_database.metadata_obj.tables[table_name]   <--- XXX no such table name
    ...
```

title: add **load_kwargs to wikipedia reader and wikipedia.page
body:
Wikipedia module has some helpful keyword arguments that allow you to deal with e.g. disambiguation pages

```
from gpt_index import WikipediaReader


if __name__ == "__main__":
    wiki_reader = WikipediaReader()
    documents = wiki_reader.load_data(["Draughts"], auto_suggest=False, redirect=True)
    print(documents)
```

Which would have failed without the keyword arguments.

Note: deliberately minor change to test PR workflow

title: [version] bump version to 0.2.1
body:
Release notes: 
GPT Index 0.2.1 is out! 
- [🪙 ](https://emojipedia.org/coin/) We now count *embedding* token usage, in addition to *LLM* token usage! 
- [🐛](https://emojipedia.org/bug/) Fix text splitting bug that was causing max prompt length exceeded errors
- [🧽](https://emojipedia.org/sponge/) Fix function signature of data loaders

title: Fix text splitter by dealing with empty tokens
body:
When a text has a lot of empty spaces, e.g. "hello  world", the separator splits the intermediate spaces into empty strings, which were counted as 0 when tokenized by itself. However when counted as part of the overall text e.g. "hello  world", it would count as its own token (this example would have three tokens, not two tokens unlike "hello world"). 

Need to deal with this edge case. Hopefully this should resolve tokenization issues.

Closes #195

Update saved index 
Closes #197

title: Gatsby index may be out of date

Exciting project! I'm looking to build an AI assistant that can answer questions using hundreds of thousands of words of loosely organized notes as context. gpt-index seems like a promising route.

---

Attempting to load index_gatsby.json from disk yields the following KeyError.

```
In [12]: index = GPTTreeIndex.load_from_disk('examples/gatsby/index_gatsby.json')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)

    341             result_dict = json.load(f)
--> 342             index_struct = cls.index_struct_cls.from_dict(result_dict["index_struct"])

    344             return cls(index_struct=index_struct, docstore=docstore, **kwargs)

KeyError: 'index_struct'
```

This could be that index_gatsby.json is from an outdated version of the project. The Paul Graham essay example index loads just fine for me.

title: Process finished with exit code 0
body:
Following the code in the gpt_index starter tutorial:

```
from gpt_index import GPTSimpleVectorIndex, SimpleDirectoryReader
from IPython.display import Markdown, display

documents = SimpleDirectoryReader('data').load_data()
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(documents)

response = index.query("What did the author do growing up?")
print(response)
```

I am receiving `Process finished with exit code 0` as opposed to `The author wrote short stories and tried to program on an IBM 1401.` which I am supposed to receive according to the tutorial.

I don't think I've provided an API key yet. That sounds like something I would have needed to have done to get a response from the LLM? However, I don't think the tutorial prompted me to put my key anywhere just yet.

title: Fix set_summary() in docs
body: This simply replaces set_summary() with set_text() calls inside docs/guides.

title: fix function signatures of data loaders
body:
Explicitly create required position args and optional keyword args for `load_data` in every data loader (subclass of `BaseReader`). 

This creates a much cleaner function interface for each subclass, and allows users to pass in positional args.

body:
Add a structured SQL index. This SQL index takes in a SQLAlchemy engine, an existing table schema, and (optionally) a set of unstructured documents. If unstructured documents are provided, the index will perform inference over these documents. 

Queries include querying with raw SQL or with natural language.

title: RateLimitError when using GPTSimpleVectorIndex
body:
I'm getting a `RateLimitError`  when constructing a `GPTSimpleVectorIndex` as given below:

```python
from gpt_index import SimpleDirectoryReader, GPTListIndex, GPTSimpleVectorIndex
documents = SimpleDirectoryReader('./data').load_data()

index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(documents)
index.save_to_disk('./index.json')
```


I'm currently using OpenAI's free trial for testing and it has a 150,000 tokens / minute hard limit. Is there some way to add a delay between API calls?

title: Fix query runner by passing llm_predictor/prompt_helper to the query properly
body: Closes #182

title: specifying the model name isn't working in the latest version
body:
Sample Code - 
```
llm = OpenAI(temperature=0.7, model_name="text-curie-001")
llm_predictor = LLMPredictor(llm)
prompt_helper = PromptHelper.from_llm_predictor(self.llm_predictor)

index = GPTListIndex(documents, llm_predictor=self.llm_predictor, prompt_helper=self.prompt_helper)
index.query(prompt, response_mode="tree_summarize")
```


The breaking change seems to have happened in [this commit](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/pull/170/commits/16eaf0c028ff21fcce6d15a938ed775b77cd8937#diff-6d4de6373201880f46d45d393878cd424ac4075bef5241c6ff0564b797ec1e55). The response builder in query is created using the default davinci `llm_predictor` [here](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/main/gpt_index/indices/query/base.py#L112) instead of the passed in predictor. This is because `query_runner` [doesn't pass in the llm_predictor](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/main/gpt_index/indices/query/query_runner.py#L85) while creating the `query obj` and [sets it later](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/main/gpt_index/indices/query/query_runner.py#L95).

title: [version] bump version to 0.1.17
body:
Release notes: 
- StringIterableReader to easily load in text strings
- Lazily load the transformers package, reduce import time 
- Remove unnecessary OpenAI dependencies

title: Remove matplotlib, plotly, scipy, and scikit-learn dependencies
body:
The use of `openai.embeddings_utils` adds some large dependencies. The actual functions being used from that package don't require any of those dependencies. 

I ported over the two functions from the [original file](https://github.com/openai/openai-python/blob/main/openai/embeddings_utils.py).

title: Suggest questions to ask, based on the documents that gpt indexes
body: would be a great way to explore large texts

title: Only import the transformers package if tiktoken is not available
body:
The `transformers` package takes a long time to load:
```sh
$ time python3 -c 'import transformers'
4.01s user 0.80s system 153% cpu 3.140 total
```
This package isn't necessary unless `tiktoken` is unavailable. By making the import lazy, the import time of `gpt_index` goes down significantly.

Before:
```sh
$ time python3 -c 'import gpt_index'
5.74s user 1.24s system 130% cpu 5.366 total
```

After:
```sh
$ time python3 -c 'import gpt_index'
2.98s user 0.74s system 179% cpu 2.074 total
```

On a related note, if you want to stop `transformers` from printing all those warnings, you need to set two environment variables:
```py
os.environ['TF_CPP_MIN_LOG_LEVEL'] = '3'
os.environ['TOKENIZERS_PARALLELISM'] = 'false'
```

title: [version] bump version to 0.1.16
body:
release notes: 

- convert to/from langchain docs

title: to/from langchain doc format
body: add methods for going for converting to/from LangChain documents

title: Add Reader for String Iterable
body:
This PR adds a reader for a string iterable. This is useful if you're working on an application in which you can easily produce, say, a list of strings you'd like to index. Usage:

```python
from gpt_index import StringIterableReader, GPTTreeIndex

documents = StringIterableReader(["I went to the store", "I bought an apple"]).load_data()
index = GPTTreeIndex(documents)
index.query("what did I buy?")

# response should be something like "You bought an apple."
```

title: [version] bump version to 0.1.15
body:
Release notes:
- Getting *sources* in the query response
- You can now see which source texts/documents contributed to the final answer.

title: [version] bump version to 0.1.14
body:
Release notes:
- Added “delete” functionality to @weaviate_io index.
- Added “update” functionality to all supported indices. Now you can update a document within GPT Index!

title: Add sources to response
body: Query responses now return a Response object that contains the text response, as well as source nodes (containing the text chunk and underlying document id).

title: add delete to Weaviate, add index update
Add delete to simple vector index, list index, keyword table index
body:
These are the most straightforward indices to implement delete on.

Next up:
- Weaviate vector index
- Faiss index
- Tree index

title: Fix Faiss index load_from_disk
body:
Closes #162 

Instead of resetting the faiss index during index construction, we raise a ValueError if faiss_index is non-empty when we build GPTFaissIndex for the first time.

Distinguishes case when index is loaded for first time (in which case we raise ValueError) vs. load_from_disk (the index will not be reset in this case).

title: Faiss load_from_disk doesn't actually work
body:
Here's a minimal example:

1. First, create and save the FAISS Index
```python
from gpt_index import GPTFaissIndex, SimpleDirectoryReader

faiss_index = faiss.IndexFlatL2(1536)
documents = SimpleDirectoryReader("data").load_data()
index = GPTFaissIndex(documents, faiss_index=faiss_index)
index.save_to_disk("index_faiss.json", faiss_index_save_path="index_faiss_core.index")
```


2. Now, try and load the same index
```python
new_index = GPTFaissIndex.load_from_disk(
    save_path="index_faiss.json", faiss_index_save_path="index_faiss_core.index"
)
print(new_index._faiss_index.ntotal)
```

Notice that 0 documents exist.


And just to verify that loading it regularly works, try this:

```python
import faiss

faiss_index = faiss.read_index("index_faiss_core.index")
print(faiss_index.ntotal)
```

This was a weird one to track down, because it doesn't actually "fail". Instead, we always return Node 0 with a distance of infinity. 

I poked around the code a bit but couldn't figure out where exactly the bug is. Separately, we should also include a quick sanity check, just ensure that the `faiss_index` isn't empty if we're loading it from disk.

title: Fix recursive directory reader with file filter
body: Closes #158

title: SimpleDirectoryReader subfolders
body:
Unless I'm doing something wrong it doesn't seem that the SimpleDirectoryReader loads documents in subfolders. Would it be possible to add this?

Thank you! 🙏

title: add an index guide
body: a visual guide on how to use each index

title: make separate_documents=True by default in vector store readers
Add embeddings to Document objects
body:
This does a few things:
- Allow users to specify embeddings when constructing Document objects manually - now each corpus of text can be associated with a user-specified embedding. 
- These embeddings will then be used during index construction and querying, for relevant embedding-based indices! We will use these embeddings instead of obtaining the embeddings ourselves (through OpenAI's endpoint).
- Allow Weaviate, Pinecone, and Faiss readers to pass in embeddings from vector stores into GPT Index

title: Fix docs: update defaults, broken links
add required_exts to simple directory reader
Allow refinement with index summary text, refactor structs
body:
- Allow refinement with the summary text on an index with include_summary option on query. 
- Move IndexStructType to a separate file (will allow us to document it better).
- Beef up query docs

title: change starter tutorial to use SimpleVectorIndex

ValueError: Error raised by inference API: Input is too long for this model, shorten your input or use 'parameters': {'truncation': 'only_first'} to run the model only on the first part.  when using gpt2 from huggingface
body:
I run into the following error when using gpt2 from huggingface - 

ValueError: Error raised by inference API: Input is too long for this model, shorten your input or use 'parameters': {'truncation': 'only_first'} to run the model only on the first part.

Can the index not be build chunk by chunk? Or am I missing something?

title: Added support for nested dirs in SimpleDirectoryReader
body:
Currently we just return a ValueError if the top-level directory we pass to SimpleDirectoryReader has sub directories.

Instead, iterate through all the subdirectories and add those to the reader.

title: fix windows encoding issue
body:
From a quick google https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49640513/unicodedecodeerror-charmap-codec-cant-decode-byte-0x9d-in-position-x-charac, it seems like this is due to an encoding issue in setup.py.

Added a GH workflow to try to catch this.

title: add Weaviate Index
body: Add GPTWeaviateIndex - similar to GPTFaissIndex, and GPTSimpleVectorIndex, we can now create an embedding index that uses Weaviate under the hood

title: correct embed_model typing to BaseEmbedding
body: also update documentation to document both OpenAIEmbedding and LangchainEmbedding

title: extend keyword filter  to keyword table + vector store
body:
Allow users to specify required keywords + exclude keywords for keyword table + vector store as additional node filters (admittedly for the keyword table, this property is a bit redundant). 

Also fixed a bug in the query_map.py for mapping to keyword table queries.

title: Add tree summarize response mode + fix text splitting bug
body:
- Adds tree summarize response mode - this can be applied on any non-tree index (list, keyword table, vector store, etc.) to synthesize the final answer
- Fix text splitting bug - originally we were computing the "empty prompt" in order to compute the chunk size in order to split the context information. However we don't want to set _all_ variables to empty, only the context variable - the other variables should be filled in and accounted for in order to compute chunk size. Use our partial formatting for this purpose.

title: Update documentation on embedding support
body: Updated documentation on the "Embedding support" and "Vector Stores" sections in the how-to guide, with the introduction of the SimpleVectorStoreIndex.

title: add response modes to queries
body: Allow users to specify mode="default" or mode="compact" during query. mode="compact" will compact given nodes to fit the maximum prompt limit, even if the nodes themselves can be much smaller (determined by chunk_size_limit)

title: Add simple embedding index
body:
Adds "simple" embedding-based index, which doesn't use Faiss under the hood, but rather a simple in-memory dictionary.

During query-time, we do brute-force nearest neighbors lookup through every item in the dictionary

title: fix GPTFaissIndex JSON serialization/deserialization issue
body:
Before the text_id could be any hashable type, but that didnt' play nice with dataclasses_json (which would reserialize the value as a string no matter the original type). So here we enforce that the text_id has to be a string 

Closes #124
